title: Perfect Reconstruction in Off-Axis Holography
description: Analyze the conditions required for achieving perfect reconstruction of a holographic image.
insight: Perfect reconstruction occurs when the illumination wave replicates the reference wave, ensuring identical image and object characteristics.
question_text:
In an off-axis hologram setup, a reference beam and an illumination beam create interference patterns on the holographic plate. The illumination wave replicates the reference wave. Under what conditions will the reconstructed image perfectly match the original object wavefront?

Use the relationships for phase addition and wavefront curvature to derive the conditions for perfect reconstruction.

solution.final_answer: The image will perfectly reconstruct if the illumination matches the reference wave in wavelength, angle, and divergence.
steps: Start with the phase addition law for holography: $$\Phi_{out} = m (\Phi_{obj} - \Phi_{ref}) + \Phi_{ill}$$.
For perfect reconstruction, the phase footprint of the illumination wave must match the reference wave: $$\Phi_{ill} = \Phi_{ref}$$.
The angle of the illumination beam must equal the reference beam: $$\theta_{ill} = \theta_{ref}$$.
The wavelength of the illumination beam must match the reference beam: $$\lambda_{ill} = \lambda_{ref}$$.
The divergence of the illumination beam must match the reference beam.
When these conditions are met, the reconstructed image matches the original object wavefront perfectly.

title: Perfect Reconstruction in Off-Axis Holography
description: Calculate the conditions required for achieving perfect reconstruction of a holographic image in terms of wavelength, angle, and phase difference.
insight: Perfect reconstruction requires matching the wavelength, angle, and phase of the illumination wave with the reference wave.
question_text:
In an off-axis holography setup, a reference wave with a wavelength of $$\lambda = 632.8 \, nm$$ illuminates the holographic plate at an angle of $$\theta_{ref} = 20^\circ$$. The illumination wave has a wavelength of $$\lambda_{ill} = 633.0 \, nm$$ and an angle of $$\theta_{ill} = 21^\circ$$.

**a)** Calculate the phase mismatch between the reference and illumination waves.
**b)** Determine if the phase difference allows for perfect reconstruction.

Use the phase mismatch formula:
$$\Delta \Phi = \frac{2 \pi}{\lambda} (\Delta \lambda) L + k (\theta_{ref} - \theta_{ill})$$, where $$L = 1.0 \, m$$ and $$k = \frac{2 \pi}{\lambda}$$.

solution.final_answer: Phase mismatch ≈ 173.2 radians. Perfect reconstruction is not achieved.
steps: 2. Substitute given values: $$\lambda = 632.8 \times 10^{-9} \, m$$, $$\Delta \lambda = 0.2 \times 10^{-9} \, m$$, $$L = 1.0 \, m$$, $$\theta_{ref} = 20^\circ$$, $$\theta_{ill} = 21^\circ$$.
1. For perfect reconstruction, $$\Delta \Phi$$ must be approximately zero.
2. Since $$173296 \text{ rad}$$ is not zero, the image will not perfectly reconstruct.
The phase mismatch is approximately $$-173296 \text{ rad}$$, and perfect reconstruction conditions are not met.

title: Phase Mismatch in Off-Axis Holography with Wavelength Shift
description: Calculate phase mismatch and reconstruction feasibility when reconstructing with a different wavelength but matched angles.
insight: Phase mismatch arises primarily from wavelength differences when beam angles are identical.
question_text:
In an off-axis holography setup, a reference wave with a wavelength of $$\lambda_{\text{ref}} = 532 \, \text{nm}$$ illuminates the holographic plate at an angle of $$\theta_{\text{ref}} = 20^\circ$$. The illumination wave during reconstruction has a wavelength of $$\lambda_{\text{ill}} = 633 \, \text{nm}$$ and the same angle of $$\theta_{\text{ill}} = 20^\circ$$.

**a)** Calculate the phase mismatch between the reference and illumination waves.
**b)** Determine if perfect reconstruction is possible.

Use the formula:
$$\Delta \Phi = \frac{2 \pi}{\lambda_{\text{ref}}} (\Delta \lambda) L + k (\theta_{\text{ref}} - \theta_{\text{ill}})$$,
where $$L = 1.0 \, \text{m}$$ and $$k = \frac{2 \pi}{\lambda_{\text{ref}}}$$.

solution.final_answer:
**a)** Phase mismatch ≈ 1.19 radians
**b)** Perfect reconstruction is **not** possible.
steps: 3. **Conclusion**: Phase mismatch is **not** a multiple of $$2\pi$$.
Even small wavelength differences (101 nm) introduce significant phase errors when angles are matched. This highlights the critical role of wavelength stability in holographic systems.

title: Longitudinal Magnification in Off-Axis Holography using Radii of Curvature
description: Calculate the longitudinal magnification of an image reconstructed from an off-axis hologram using the radii of curvature formula.
insight: Longitudinal magnification depends on the ratio of radii of curvature of the wavefronts in the object and image spaces, scaled by the wavelength and magnification factor.
question_text:
In an off-axis hologram setup, the object wavefront has a radius of curvature of $$R_{obj} = 200 \text{ mm}$$, and the image wavefront has a radius of curvature of $$R_{out,m} = 600 \text{ mm}$$. The wavelengths are $$\lambda_1 = 500 \text{ nm}$$ and $$\lambda_2 = 600 \text{ nm}$$. The system has a magnification factor of $$m = 1.5$$.

Using the longitudinal magnification formula:
$$MAG_{long} = m \frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1} \left(\frac{R_{out,m}}{R_{obj}}\right)^2$$,
calculate the longitudinal magnification of the image.

steps: Start with the longitudinal magnification formula: $$MAG_{long} = m \frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1} \left(\frac{R_{out,m}}{R_{obj}}\right)^2$$.
Substitute the given values: $$m = 1.5$$, $$\lambda_2 = 600 \text{ nm}$$, $$\lambda_1 = 500 \text{ nm}$$, $$R_{out,m} = 600 \text{ mm}$$, $$R_{obj} = 200 \text{ mm}$$.
The longitudinal magnification of the image is approximately 16.2.

title: Lateral Magnification in Off-Axis Holography
description: Calculate the lateral magnification of an image reconstructed from an off-axis hologram.
insight: Lateral magnification in off-axis holography depends on the wavelength, angles, and radii of curvature of the reference and object beams.
question_text:
In an off-axis hologram setup, the object beam has a wavelength of $$\lambda_1 = 633 \, \text{nm}$$, and the reconstructed image uses a wavelength of $$\lambda_2 = 543 \, \text{nm}$$. The object beam has a radius of curvature $$R_{obj} = 100 \, \text{mm}$$, and the image beam has a radius of curvature $$R_{out,m,x} = 150 \, \text{mm}$$. The angles of the object and image beams are $$\theta_{obj} = 30^\circ$$ and $$\theta_{out,m} = 45^\circ$$, respectively. Determine the lateral magnification of the reconstructed image.

Use the relationship:
$$MAG_{lateral,x} = m \frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1} \frac{\cos(\theta_{obj})}{\cos(\theta_{out,m})} \frac{R_{out,m,x}}{R_{obj}}$$.

steps:
Start with the lateral magnification formula:
$$MAG_{lateral,x} = m \frac{\lambda_2}{\lambda_1} \frac{\cos(\theta_{obj})}{\cos(\theta_{out,m})} \frac{R_{out,m,x}}{R_{obj}}$$.
The lateral magnification of the image is approximately 1.57.
